awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Examining the Impact of an Industry-aligned, STEM Problem Based Learning Curriculum on Native Hawaiian and Underrepresented Youth Workforce Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Project STEMulate will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing and testing an innovative approach for promoting STEM competency, interest, persistence, preparation and entry into the STEM workforce among Native Hawaiians and other underrepresented, low-income, first generation high school students. Building on a successful postsecondary model, this project will adapt the model for implementation at the secondary level. The model will be redesigned to align with standards and incorporate age appropriate problem-based learning pedagogy and practices. A robust workforce development component will be added, extending the summer program into the academic year with student industry internships. Three field advancing research questions, with sub-questions, will be explored. Of notable significance is the deep convergence of Hawaiian culture and STEM learning with real world industry-aligned problem solving and workforce development opportunities across three Hawaiian Islands. Few, if any, ITEST projects have examined the profound potential impact such convergence could have on these specific target populations. Thus, the proposed work will add to the literature while also directly impacting hundreds of secondary students and teachers, postsecondary students, and others. Project partners such as the Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii EPSCoR Ike Wai, Pacific Disaster Center, Hui O Waa Kaulua, and Upward Bound will bring significant capacity, expertise, and resources to all phases of the work. 

Over a three-year period, approximately 225 high school students enrolled in Upward Bound and Upward Board Math and Science summer programs at the University of Hawaii Maui College, University of Hawaii Hilo, and Windward Community College will participate in Project STEMulate (75 students/site). The summer program will employ a flipped classroom approach, with much of the industry-aligned, STEM problem solving and hands on work being conducted as a group, during summer classroom sessions led by STEM instructors and undergraduate students. Content review and pre/post classroom session learning will occur via recorded videos and other materials during unstructured summer study hall periods. During the academic year, twenty-five of the summer participants will be selected to participate in student industry internships with local and project partners. Using a quasi-experimental, pre-post research design matching target youth with youth in two comparison groups, students will engage in various aspects of the project depending on which group they are assigned. The three research questions the project will explore include: (1) How does using technology-rich STEM problem-based learning (PBL) affect low-income and Native Hawaiian students' interest in STEM careers? (2) Does the extension of a technology-rich PBL approach in an internship increase students' interest, motivation, and skill to enter the STEM workforce? And (3) Are there additive benefits from multiple summers of exposure? Does one summer alone produce efficient results? Data sources will include: (1) pre and post-surveys, (2) team collaboration surveys, (3) interviews, and (4) student final products. Formative and summative evaluations will be conducted by an experienced external evaluator. The project will disseminate data, curricula, and training materials broadly to local high school staff, its local and project partners, and through the Council for Opportunities in Education webinars offered to summer-program educators serving over 70,000 low-income students nationwide.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project STEMulate developed STEM self-efficacy, motivation, and interest in underrepresented students by providing a technology-rich STEM Problem-based Learning (PBL) curriculum that actively engaged students in real-world, technology-based problem solving and learning.  Project STEMulate crafted a teacher training curriculum to expose and provide teachers with the mindset and skills to establish a STEM PBL learning environment. Students, teachers, and STEM Industry partners connected through the STEM PBL curriculum to strengthen the STEM-workforce pipeline.  Over the course of three years, 148 students engaged with the STEM PBL curriculum and 50 teachers participated in the STEM PBL training course.  Overall, this study marks the case that out-of-school time (OST) programs, particularly summer programs, create an important opportunity to enhance student learning, cultivate students’ interest in STEM careers,and provide them with opportunities to accelerate 21st century learning idioms such as collaboration, critical thinking and problem-solving. 

The STEM PBL Teacher Training - Project STEMulate identified five core tenets including: 1) Real-world Focus; 2) Student Driven & Student Centered; 3) Open Ended Outcomes; 4) Collaborative; and 5) Interdisciplinary.  These core tenets were provided to teachers as a framework to embrace their role as a facilitator of learning and cultivate a PBL environment within their classrooms.  Teachers engaged in a 9-week hybrid training course that included: 1) Face-to-face Sessions: a community building orientation session and a closing reflection session; 2) Discussion Posts to reflect on their own ideology and practice; 3) PBL Mini Activities to participate in the PBL process; and 4) PBL Lesson Planning to support the design and backward planning of PBL lessons.  Consistent throughout each year, the largest gains for teachers were: improved science instruction, as compared to items on how teachers improved their overall teaching.  Other notable gains were for increased confidence in teaching about STEM careers and likely connections and implementation of Problem-based Learning activities.  Research results indicated that the majority of teachers were motivated toward adopting core PBL practices into their instruction during the Summer Academy and extending it to the regular school year. Teachers reported their PBL experience provided them with additional, meaningful benefits such as being able to provide more constructive and meaningful feedback to students, while encouraging them to persist through challenges. In addition, teachers reported experiencing increased motivation, recognized meaningful support, and experimented implementation of newly learned skills. 

The STEM PBL curriculum model —adapted for diverse underrepresented populations, effectively stimulated STEM interest and learning in high school students for productive participation in the STEM-related workforce of the future. The curriculum model included a combination of 1) a Problem-based Learning setting, where students worked in collaborative groups to understand and work towards solution pathways and were guided and facilitated by a teacher team of three; 2) authentic learning experiences such as guest speakers, site visits, field trips, and other hands-on activities to support student learning including the presentation of the real-world problem and mentoring by a local STEM Industry Partner; and 3) flipped classroom video modules on scientific inquiry, logic and reasoning, and technical science writing and communication that students watched on their own time.  The STEM PBL curriculum was integrated into the programmatic Summer Academy at three Upward Bound sites in Hawaiʻi (University of Hawaii Maui College, Windward Community College-ʻOahu, and University of Hawaii Hilo).  Results showed that students participating in the STEM PBL curriculum had higher statistically significant gains in both science self-efficacy and motivation. This supports the notion that with hands-on exploration and problem-solving and searching for solutions to a real world problem, students developed interest in activities they performed and believed they could perform them well. Through hands-on experiences, students met and worked with STEM Industry partners in authentic ways. Research results indicated STEMulate students were more interested in participating in the STEM careers and fields than the comparison group. Findings clearly demonstrate a relationship between student science self-efficacy and motivation and their perceptions of PBL and their interest in future STEM careers. 

These findings are relevant beyond this population. Project STEMulate has shown traction and efficacy as a replicable model, and would very likely succeed in many other contexts sharing the same socioeconomic and cultural factors as proven barriers for access to STEM learning. Project STEMulate broadens participation through the inclusion of cultural relevance. The theme of cultural relevance emerged through research analysis, suggesting that PBL provides avenues for the inclusion of cultural knowledge and lived experiences of students as valid sources of learning.  This emerging finding supports the use of STEM PBL as a practical model for inclusion and broadening participation.  Although this work has already added to the knowledge base in this area, it still calls for additional studies that will validate and refine research on improving STEM learning opportunities for underserved populations and communities everywhere.

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2021
Modified by: Jaymee Nanasi Davis
